generated_text: The structure of hydrate is of great importance to the understanding of the physical properties of the hydrate system and its applications. However, the structure of hydrate is still a controversial issue. In this work, we report the structure of neon hydrate at high pressure and temperature. The results provide a new insight into the structure of hydrate.

The foundations of quantum theory are a major open problem in the history of science. In this paper, we provide a purely categorical approach to the foundations of quantum theory. The axioms are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. This approach addresses a question about the mathematical foundations of quantum theory raised in reconstruction programs such as those of von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasitic animals that are of great interest to both basic and applied science. The evolutionary origin of the myxozoan body plan, which is characterized by a distinctive structure, the polar capsule, is a long-standing question. Here, we report the results of a comparative analysis of the genomes of two distantly related myxozoans and a cnidarian parasite. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content.

The ability of viruses to evade the host immune response is a common strategy used by pathogens to survive and propagate in their host. In this study, we show that the SARS-CoV-2 accessory protein Orf6 is able to block the nuclear translocation of STAT1 and STAT2, two key transcription factors that are critical for the induction of IFN-stimulated genes. Our results demonstrate that Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1, a protein complex that mediates nuclear import. We show that a methionine-to-arginine substitution at residue 58 impairs Orf6 binding to the Nup98-Rae1 complex and abolishes its ability to block the nuclear import of STAT1 and STAT2. All together our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. Our findings have important implications for the development of antiviral strategies against SARS-CoV-2. (Show more)

Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of these channels. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of the Hv1 channel. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion people by 2050, and the demand for food is expected to increase by 50% by 2030 and by 70% by 2050. This study shows that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase to values much larger than present-day values as the Earth’s mean temperature increases. This higher CV is due both to an increase in the standard deviation of yields and to a decrease in mean yields. The probability that the top four maize-exporting countries have simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year is presently virtually zero, but it increases to 7% under 2 °C warming and 86% under 4 °C warming. Our results portend rising instability in global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes.

The coexistence of species with different feeding preferences is a fundamental challenge in ecology. We show that DNA metabarcoding can be used to quantify the degree to which different species of large mammals partition food resources. We show that the degree of diet overlap is strongly correlated with the degree of diet similarity, and that the degree of diet overlap is strongly correlated with the degree of diet similarity. These results suggest that the degree of diet overlap may be a better predictor of competition than the degree of diet similarity. These results have implications for our understanding of the mechanisms that maintain species diversity in large mammal communities.

We conducted a large-scale survey of small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. Our findings suggest that the pandemic is already having a significant impact on small businesses, with many laying off workers and closing their doors. Moreover, many small businesses are financially fragile, and the majority are planning to apply for loans under the CARES Act. However, many anticipate problems with accessing the program, such as bureaucratic hassles and difficulties establishing eligibility.

Plastic debris is one of the most visible consequences of human activities in the ocean. However, the magnitude of the problem is still unclear. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. Our observations of the size distribution of floating plastic debris point at important size-selective sinks removing millimeter-sized fragments of floating plastic on a large scale. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of the solar system is one of the most important questions in astronomy. The age of the solar system is a key parameter for the understanding of the formation of the solar system. In this work, we determined the age of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grains have interstellar exposure ages of <300 Ma and >1 Ga. The majority of the grains have interstellar lifetimes of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. This indicates that the grains were part of aggregates in the interstellar medium. Furthermore, we show that the bulk of the cosmogenic nuclides of the grains were produced in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to the enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. The results are important for the understanding of the formation of the solar system.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to reproduce is one of the most important traits in nature. In this study, we show that the ability to reproduce is also one of the most plastic. We show that the ability to reproduce is plastic in a way that increases the reproductive output of the mother.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. Several studies point to α-syn oligomerization and aggregation as a mediator of neurotoxicity in synucleinopathies including MSA. Here, we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which was well tolerated in a phase II trial in patients with epilepsy, is able to limit the progressive toxicity of α-syn aggregation in a mouse model of MSA. Our results suggest that VX-765 is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This would be a major step forward in the treatment of MSA and other synucleinopathies.

The endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels and is the first line of defense against the body. It is responsible for controlling the flow of blood, the exchange of oxygen and nutrients, and the response to injury. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells that are specialized to perform these functions. This paper describes the structure of the endothelium and how it communicates with itself.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous amounts of data, which are needed by many stakeholders, including policy makers, epidemiological modelers, and researchers. We describe the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a wide range of data on the COVID-19 pandemic, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available in public health surveillance. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This paper describes the data sources and signals, and provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion-channel family in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological processes, such as the control of heart rate and blood pressure, the transmission of nerve impulses, and the regulation of muscle contraction. The selectivity filter and the activation gate are functionally and structurally coupled in this ion-channel family. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is influenced by the host and its environment. The role of the gut microbiome in health and disease is just beginning to be understood, and the potential for the microbiome to be manipulated therapeutically is being explored. In this study, we identify a large number of natural products that are produced by anaerobic fungi that inhabit the gastrointestinal tracts of herbivores. These fungi are a potential source of new compounds for the treatment of infections caused by antibiotic-resistant bacteria.

Social dominance is a key aspect of social behavior, yet the role of personality traits in the establishment of social hierarchies remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that predisposes individuals to become subordinate, directly influences social dominance in rats and identifies an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of anxiety in social behavior and may lead to the development of new treatments for anxiety-related social disorders. The design of mechanical structures with desired responses is of great importance for a wide range of applications. However, the use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we propose a digital synthesis approach to synthesize composite structures with multiple materials and digitally designed patterns. Within the structures, different materials play distinct roles yet seamlessly collaborate through sophisticated deformation mechanisms to produce the target behaviors. The synthesized structures are effectively manufactured via multimaterial fabrication with different elastomers with distinct behaviors and their highly nonlinear responses are physically and accurately realized in experiments. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. This work provides a new paradigm for the design of mechanical structures with desired responses. It is expected to have a significant impact on the development of mechanical devices in various fields.

The hemoglobin (Hb) system is a key regulator of the oxygen carrying capacity of the blood. The Hb system is also a target of the let-7 microRNA pathway. Here we show that the IGF2BP1 protein, a downstream element of the let-7 pathway, can mediate the reversal of the Hb expression pattern in human erythroblasts. This reversal is achieved by a reduction in the expression of the adult Hb genes and an increase in fetal Hb. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of Hb expression in humans.

Cancer is the number one cause of death worldwide. Despite the development of new therapies, the survival of cancer patients remains poor. In this study, we found that the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling pathway confers resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent peroxidation of phospholipids. This resistance is mediated by the induction of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. In addition, we found that the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction shows therapeutic promise in preclinical models. Our findings provide a rationale for the development of combination therapies for cancer treatment. (Show more)

Hypertension is the most common risk factor for heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of the treatment of heart failure. The most widely used drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers. However, the use of these drugs is associated with the development of heart failure. Here, we show that the major drugs of this class of drugs promote vascular remodeling through the activation of the Ca2+ sensor STIM. Our findings may help to improve the safety of these drugs.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the management of 10 million hectares of federal land. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of early-seral bird populations, but the opposite occurred for older-forest–associated species. This is partly due to the loss of older forests to fire on federal land and continued clearcutting elsewhere. The NWFP has been effective in halting the decline of early-seral bird populations, but the policy has not yet reversed the decline of older-forest–associated species. Our findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge for the medical community. In this work, we present a computational approach to design new antibiotics. The design strategy is based on the prediction of the solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity of acylide antibiotics. We show that the best candidate designed by us is active against antibiotic-resistant pathogens and that it is more active than telithromycin, the current standard of care. The design strategy presented here can be used to develop new antibiotics for other antibiotic-resistant pathogens. View Full-Text

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, which makes them difficult to train and apply in practice. Here, we introduce a network architecture based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice, and automatically adapts to different problems. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. Before 800 ka, lake levels were lower, indicating a climate drier than today, and water levels changed frequently. Following the MPT high-amplitude lake level variations dominate the record. The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime has become ubiquitous. This study shows that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a well-known event in the geological record. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the Osmium isotope composition of the YDB samples is consistent with the terrestrial origin of Os in these samples. In addition, the rare earth element patterns and Sr and Nd isotopes of the 2- to 5-mm spherules indicate that their source lies in 1.5-Ga Quebecia terrain in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America.

The role of cytotoxic T lymphocyte antigen-4 (CTLA-4) in the development of autoimmunity is controversial. Here, we show that the loss of CTLA-4 in adult mice results in a spectrum of autoimmunity, which is not observed in congenital deficiency. Moreover, we show that the loss of CTLA-4 in adult mice has opposing effects on different autoimmune models. Thus, CTLA-4 deficiency affects both central and peripheral tolerance and Treg cell-mediated suppression.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We used a combination of genomic and fossil data to trace the evolution of beetles and to estimate the timing and rates of beetle diversification. Our results show that beetles diversified in the presence of angiosperms, and that plant cell wall-degrading enzymes may have been key to the Mesozoic diversification of herbivorous beetles. These results suggest that the evolution of beetles may have been driven by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding enzymes that enable digestion of plant cell walls.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work has the potential to accelerate the development of next-generation antibodies and vaccines against SARS-CoV-2 variants. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. In this study, we report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results have implications for the design of future experiments and the study of CCE in general.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. APOE4 is associated with an ∼twofold increased risk for AD, whereas APOE2 is associated with a ∼12-fold decreased risk. These data put APOE central to AD pathophysiology, but it is not yet clear how APOE alleles modify AD risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the phagocytic capacity of astrocytes that is highly dependent on APOE isoform. APOE2 enhances the rate of phagocytosis of synapses by astrocytes, whereas APO4 decreases it. The Earth's inner core is a solid ball of iron that is 1,700 km in diameter and 1,300 km in radius. It is the densest part of the Earth, with a density of 13.0–13.5 g/cm3, which is 13–15 times that of water. The inner core is thought to have formed when molten iron cooled below the melting point. However, the nucleation mechanism of the stable, hexagonal, close-packed (hcp) phase of iron, which is the main component of the inner core, has not been well understood. Here, we show that the nucleation of the body-centered, cubic (bcc) phase of iron is much more likely than that of the hcp phase. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced reactivity of the brain to methylphenidate, a drug that increases extracellular dopamine (DA). This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, which are common symptoms of marijuana addiction.

The brain’s processing of language is the focus of intense study, but our understanding of its mechanisms is incomplete. Here, we show that the most powerful machine learning models for predicting the brain’s activity when people process language also capture much of the variance in the brain’s activity during language processing. This suggests that predictive processing may be a fundamental mechanism for how the brain represents language. We also find that the models’ neural fits correlate with how well the models predict behavior on a critical task. These results provide computational evidence for predictive processing in the language comprehension system in the human brain.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning. However, it is not clear whether DL is a special case of a general method, or whether it is a special case of a more general method. In this paper, we show that DL is a special case of a more general method. We also show that the success of DL is due to the fact that it is a special case of a more general method.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including a failure to understand exponential growth. This paper discusses a classic experiment that has been cited more than 1,000 times in the past 45 y. It shows that the study’s critical design flaws were overlooked at the time, and that the study’s conclusion was still supported in the 1970s. However, in the 2020s, the study is increasingly cited in the context of the pandemic. This paper discusses the implications of this for the study of human cognition and the interpretation of scientific evidence.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years. It is caused by two bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae, which causes the nerve-damaging disease leprosy, and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which causes a nonnerve-damaging disease known as lepromatous leprosy. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis and compared it with that of M. leprae. We found that the two bacteria are remarkably similar, despite their ancient separation. This suggests that the two bacteria have retained many of the same genes, and that the genes that have been lost are not essential for the survival of the bacteria. This may be important for understanding the evolution of the disease. (PsycINFO Database Record

The dynamics of quantum entanglement and entropy is a key open problem in quantum physics. In this work, we provide a complete solution to this problem for the paradigmatic case of the Heisenberg spin chain. Our result is based on a combination of integrability and quasiparticle concepts. This allows us to compute the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit, which is the appropriate regime for a complete understanding of the problem. Our result is exact and applicable to a wide class of models.

The COVID-19 pandemic has affected the lives of billions of people worldwide. The only available vaccines are based on the spike protein of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19. However, the spike protein is a large protein with many potential epitopes, and the immune response to it is complex. Here, we describe a vaccine that uses a modified version of the spike protein that is more immunogenic and protective than the wild-type protein. This vaccine is easy to manufacture and can be used in mass vaccination programs.

Plague, caused by the bacterium Yersinia pestis, is one of the most devastating diseases in human history. Today, most human plague cases are caused by inhalation of infectious droplets, but the historical spread of plague in Europe is poorly understood. Here, we describe a compartmental model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. Using Bayesian inference, we found that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for pneumonic or rodent transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study provides a new perspective on the history of plague and the role of human ectoparasites in the spread of disease. It also provides a framework for understanding the historical spread of disease in the context of vector transmission.

The evolution of the brain is one of the most important topics in the study of animal intelligence. However, the evolution of brain size is not always a good proxy for the evolution of brain power. This study shows that the evolution of the brain is characterized by the following four major shifts in neuron–brain scaling. The most dramatic increases in brain neurons occurred independently with the appearance of birds and mammals, resulting in convergent neuron scaling in the two endotherm lineages. The other two major increases in the number of neurons happened in core land birds and anthropoid primates, which are two groups known for their cognitive prowess.

TRAP1 (TNF receptor-associated protein) is a mitochondrial molecular chaperone that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal and transformed cells is more complex than previously appreciated. We have shown that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings.

Actin filaments are the building blocks of the cytoskeleton, and their disassembly is essential for many cellular processes. Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF)/cofilin is the key regulator of actin filament disassembly. However, how it does so in a physiological context, where filaments are interconnected and under mechanical stress, remains unclear. Here, we show that ADF/cofilin-induced mechanical forces, such as those generated by twisting filaments, enhance its severing activity. This mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF/cofilin’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our findings have implications for our understanding of actin filament disassembly in cells and for the design of new actin-based motors. They also have implications for the design of new materials, such as cytoskeleton-like networks, which are based on actin filaments.

Fructose, a common sweetener found in many soft drinks, may be a stronger appetite suppressant than glucose, a common sweetener found in many processed foods. This study provides evidence that the effects of fructose versus glucose on brain, hormone, and appetitive responses to food cues and food-approach behavior may be mediated by differences in the metabolic fate of these two sweeteners.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, which allowed us to reconstruct the history of the Malagasy people. We find that the Malagasy people are a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian people, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The admixture happened recently, suggesting a rapid settlement of Madagascar during the last millennium. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. Our results provide a new perspective on the history of Madagascar. They also provide a new perspective on the history of the Indian Ocean. View Full-Text

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions of others on Facebook. This is a large-scale experiment, with more than 600,000 people, and the results are robust to a range of analyses. The results suggest that people are influenced by the emotions of others, even when they do not interact with them in person. This is a significant finding, as it suggests that people are influenced by the emotions of others, even when they do not interact with them in person. It also suggests that in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion. Finally, it suggests that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people.

Messenger RNA (mRNA) sequences can be modified after transcription, and these modifications can have important effects on mRNA function. In this study, we show that the presence of one of the most common modifications, pseudouridine (Ψ), in the mRNA sequence can have a modest impact on translation. Our work suggests that the presence of Ψ in the mRNA sequence can modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. These findings have implications for understanding the role of mRNA modifications in the regulation of gene expression.

This study shows that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, social engagement, and time use. This study also shows that this feeling is associated with positive outcomes even after controlling for factors such as socioeconomic status, depressive symptoms, and health. These findings have implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging.

The evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is a well-known phenomenon, but the underlying mechanisms are poorly understood. Here, we show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. The existence of this body size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These three independent body size increases and a shared aquatic optimum size are consistent with control by differences in the scaling of energetic intake and cost functions with body size between the terrestrial and aquatic realms. Under this energetic model, thermoregulatory costs constrain minimum size, whereas limitations on feeding efficiency constrain maximum size. The optimum size occurs at an intermediate value where thermoregulatory costs are low but feeding efficiency remains high. Rather than being released from size pressures, water-dwelling mammals are driven and confined to larger body sizes by the strict energetic demands of the aquatic medium.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. The temperature at which rhinovirus replicates most efficiently in the human respiratory tract is unknown. Here, we show that rhinovirus replicates more efficiently at the temperature of the nasal cavity than at the temperature of the body core. We also show that the temperature-dependent growth phenotype of rhinovirus is dependent on the antiviral response of the host.

Bacteria are constantly exposed to their environment, and must be able to sense and respond to changes in the external conditions. In this study, we show that the surface-attached Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the activity of its pili to sense the mechanical activity of the surface. This mechanosensory system is part of the Chp chemosensory system, which regulates the production of the second messenger cAMP and the expression of hundreds of genes, including key virulence factors. Our results demonstrate that the mechanical activity of the pili promotes the long-term attachment of the bacteria to the surface, which in turn stimulates additional virulence and biofilm-inducing pathways. This mechanochemical model for surface sensing is unique among bacteria and may be a general mechanism for sensing mechanical activity in the environment.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the last decades. However, the impact of pesticides on the quality of surface water is still poorly understood. We show that the presence of pesticides in surface water is very common, but that the concentrations are often high enough to cause harm to aquatic life. This is a major concern, as surface water is used for drinking, bathing, fishing, and recreation. Our results suggest that the use of pesticides in agriculture needs to be reduced, and that the use of newer-generation pesticides should be prioritized.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on the world, and the virus has spread to many animal species. In this study, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, a species that is susceptible to infection. Our findings suggest that deer may be a reservoir for SARS-CoV-2, and that the virus has been circulating in deer for several months. This study highlights the need for a more comprehensive understanding of the ecology of SARS-CoV-2, and the importance of a One Health approach to mitigate the spread of the virus. (Show more)

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, people, and the climate. This paper examines the causes of the proliferation of large dams in the developing world, the impacts of these dams, and the solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) protein is the primary pathological hallmark of the disease. However, the immune response in AD is often attributed to sustained microglial activation in response to Aβ deposits and cell death. Here, we show that neurons are also capable of producing a variety of potent immune factors, and that the accumulation of Aβ in the brain is sufficient to trigger a neuron-specific inflammatory response. This study reveals the Aβ-burdened neuron as a primary proinflammatory agent, implicating the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ as a significant immunological component in the AD pathogenesis. Our findings have important implications for the development of AD therapeutics. View Full-Text

The domestication of the chicken (Gallus gallus domesticus) is one of the most important events in the history of human culture. The earliest evidence for the domestication of the chicken is from the Near East, where it was domesticated at least 7,000 y ago. However, the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of the chicken is still missing. Here we present a detailed analysis of the faunal remains from the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, which shows that the exploitation of chickens was widespread and economically important in the Hellenistic period. Our results provide new insights into the history of the domestication and economic exploitation of the chicken. They also shed light on the role of the Near East in the spread of the chicken to Europe. (Show more)

The folding of proteins is a major unsolved problem in biology. This work shows that the folding of maltose binding protein, a large protein, is a complex process with distinct steps. The work also shows that the folding of proteins can be studied in great detail at the molecular level.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a key mechanism for regulating gene expression in bacteria. In this study, we show that the decapping enzyme responsible for removing the cap from Np4-capped RNAs is also activated by stress, and that it prefers to remove capped substrates over their capped counterparts. This enzyme, which is normally inactive in the presence of disulfide stress, is able to recognize capped 5′ termini by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini, resulting in a one-nucleotide shift in substrate specificity. The unconventional manner in which this enzyme recognizes capped 5′ termini and its differential impact on the rates at which such termini are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress. Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcomes. The mechanisms involved in the immune dysfunction during sepsis are not fully understood. In this study, we show that arginine, a major amino acid in the diet, is a key molecule in the immune dysfunction induced by sepsis. We also show that citrulline, a metabolite of arginine, is a promising molecule to restore the immune function in sepsis. These results provide evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis.

The biomass of the biosphere is the sum of the masses of all living organisms. It is a fundamental quantity that is used to understand the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined and highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our analysis reveals that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Finally, we highlight that the mass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined and report the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and are essential for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere.

We introduce a new model of self-organized criticality (SOC) and show that it exhibits a scaling limit with SOC behavior. This model is a continuous version of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models and show that the model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena. Our aim is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide range of applications in electronics, photonics, and quantum technologies. It is a promising material for the next generation of devices, but its properties are difficult to control. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its bandgap can be tuned, by applying strain. This opens up new possibilities for the design of diamond-based devices.

The discovery of antifungal peptides is a recent development in the field of natural product chemistry. These peptides are promising candidates for the development of new classes of antifungal agents. However, the structural basis of their antifungal activity is not well understood. Here, we report the structure of one of the most active antifungal peptides, NCR044, and show that it binds to multiple phosphoinositides in germlings of the plant pathogen Botrytis cinerea. This peptide also exhibits potent fungicidal activity against multiple plant fungal pathogens. Our work provides a structural basis for the antifungal activity of this peptide and paves the way for future development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes. In this study, we provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome. We show that the sperm proteome undergoes substantial compositional changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that female-derived proteins begin to associate with sperm immediately after mating, and they comprise nearly 20% of the postmating sperm proteome. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This work will be of interest to the broader scientific community and to the public interested in the reproductive system.

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, through a domain called A1. We show that force can switch the conformation of A1, and that this mechanism can be used to activate VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism is important for the pathophysiology of von Willebrand disease, a common bleeding disorder.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been the subject of intense study for the past decade. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been more difficult to study, and the lack of a comprehensive database has hindered the ability to understand the impact of viruses on human health. This study provides a database of human-associated viruses, which is the largest of its kind. It also provides a resource for the study of virus–disease associations, which are found in this study.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, the ACI is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the lack of high-resolution and simultaneous observations of diurnal aerosol loading and cloud microphysical properties. To overcome this conundrum, we introduce the dual-field-of-view (FOV) high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL) for simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties, especially water cloud microphysical properties. This instrument, verified by the Monte Carlo simulation and coincident observations of other techniques, was used to conduct continuous observations of aerosols and clouds over Beijing. The observations show that the increased aerosol loading led to increased droplet number concentration and decreased droplet effective radius, which is consistent with expectations. However, the aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The temperature of the early Earth has been a topic of debate for decades. The temperature of the surface of the Earth has been inferred from the isotopic composition of marine sediments. However, this interpretation has been subject to question due to uncertainties regarding oceanic isotopic compositions, diagenetic or metamorphic resetting of the isotopic record, and depositional environments. Here, we present a method by which to assess the temperature history inferred from the isotopic evidence. We show that the ancestral temperature of the surface of the Earth was ∼80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. Ion channels are the main ion conduits in the cell membrane. They open and close their pore gates to regulate ion flow. K+ channels commonly possess two pore gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally show no C-type inactivation. We found that the BK channel’s activation gate may spatially overlap or coexist with the C-type inactivation gate at or near the selectivity filter. C-type inactivation in BK channels is closed state-dependent and its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. Our findings provide insights into the mechanism of K+ channel regulation. They also provide a possible explanation for the BK channel’s unique properties, such as its normal closing and no C-type inactivation. These findings may also have implications for the development of K+ channel modulators.

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with the Plasmodium parasite infecting over 3 billion people. Despite the development of antimalarial drugs, the disease remains a major public health problem. In this study, we show that the malaria parasite, Plasmodium falciparum, alters the physical properties of the erythrocyte, which are critical for invasion. Our findings suggest that the parasite primes the erythrocyte surface, reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion. This study provides a new perspective on the invasion process and opens up new avenues for the development of new antimalarial strategies. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide range of applications in electronics, photonics, and quantum technologies. It is a promising material for the next generation of devices, but its properties are difficult to control. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its bandgap can be tuned, by applying strain. This opens up new possibilities for the design of diamond-based devices.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality in humans. In this study, we show that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide mechanistic insights into the impact of ambient humidity on influenza virus infection and may help to develop strategies to reduce the impact of influenza virus in the temperate regions. The brain is thought to build a tree-like structure of the sentence as a whole, from the top down, but there is no direct evidence for this. Here, we show that the brain’s activity increases with each word in a sentence, but suddenly decreases whenever a new phrase is formed. This suggests that the brain is able to merge words into phrases, and that the merge operation applies equally to arbitrary-sized linguistic objects. Our results provide initial evidence for a neural implementation of a left-corner parser, which is thought to be the first stage of sentence processing.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a key regulator of development. Axin is a key component of the pathway, and its activity is critical for the pathway to function. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin in vertebrates are differentially regulated on the transcriptional and proteostatic level. This differential regulation confers tissue-specific responsiveness to the pathway.
The brain circuit that promotes overeating is described.

Nitrogen is the most important nutrient for plant growth, and the availability of nitrogen is the major factor limiting crop yields. The use of nitrogen-fixing bacteria in agriculture has been limited by the lack of a sustainable way to control the activity of the bacteria in the soil. Here, we demonstrate a method to control the activity of nitrogen-fixing bacteria in the soil, using a plant-derived signal. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work may lead to a sustainable way to increase crop yields. (Show more)

The Amazon is the world’s most important tropical forest and a critical ecosystem for the global climate. Despite substantial investments in remote-sensed forest monitoring, the Amazon is losing forest at an alarming rate. We study a community-based monitoring program that was designed to reduce deforestation in the Peruvian Amazon. We find that the program reduced deforestation in the communities that participated in the program. However, the estimated effects are imprecise, and the program may have unintended consequences. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals have evolved a wide range of hearing organs, but they are all part of the body. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can hear without a body, because its web acts as an acoustic antenna. The web is not only the spider’s home, but also its acoustic sensor. The spider can hear without a body, and the web can be regenerated.

The health and climate impacts of air pollution and greenhouse gases are difficult to disentangle. We show that the health benefits of reducing fossil-fuel-related emissions are much larger than previously thought. This is because the chemical influence of air pollution on dust contributes to the aerosol cooling, which in turn increases rainfall over densely populated regions. Our results indicate that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to be a global health crisis. The development of vaccines is a major step forward in the fight against the virus. However, the high cost of the currently approved vaccines may limit their global access. Here, we report the design and synthesis of a SARS-CoV-2 receptor-binding domain (RBD) variant that is more manufacturable and immunogenic than the currently used Wuhan-Hu-1 RBD. The engineered RBD can be expressed in large quantities in bacteria, and the resulting vaccine can induce antibodies that bind to the variants of concern. The engineered RBD can also be used to design a virus-like particle vaccine, which can reduce the weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. These results suggest that the engineered RBD may be a promising candidate for the development of a vaccine.

The study of the development of the pigment cells of the skin, called iridophores, is a model for the study of the neural crest, a group of cells that are derived from the neural crest and that are involved in the development of many tissues and organs. We show that the zebrafish homolog of the ALK/Ltk receptor is involved in the development of iridophores. This is the first demonstration of the involvement of ALK/Ltk receptors in the development of neural crest-derived tissues.

The emergence of plague, a disease that has plagued humanity for millennia, is a complex story that has been difficult to unravel. Here, we present a large dataset of ancient Yersinia pestis genomes, which provide a unique opportunity to explore the evolution of this pathogen. Our results reveal a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct lineage that persisted over millennia without significant parallel diversification, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents. We also discover the presence of the flea-adapted form of plague in Bronze Age Iberia, previously only identified in in the Caucasus and the Volga regions, suggesting a much wider geographic spread of this form of plague. Together, these data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. This work provides a foundation for future studies of the history of plague and its impact on human history. (Show more)

This work examines the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 presidential election and Joe Biden in the 2020 presidential election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted support for Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia, but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies. The findings have implications for understanding the political consequences of masculinity.

The management of agricultural systems can affect the amount of carbon (C) stored in the soil. In this study, we show that the management of annual cropping systems on a Midwestern Mollisol can be optimized to increase the amount of C stored in the soil. We show that the addition of legumes and manure, the incorporation of cover crops, and the integration of rotational grazing can increase the amount of C stored in the soil. These results highlight the importance of well-managed grasslands in climate-smart agriculture.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need to identify and characterize viruses that pose a risk of spillover and spread in humans. We used expert opinion and scientific evidence to identify risk factors for zoonotic virus spillover and spread in humans. We then developed a risk ranking framework and interactive web tool, SpillOver, that estimates a risk score for wildlife-origin viruses, creating a comparative risk assessment of viruses with uncharacterized zoonotic spillover potential alongside those already known to be zoonotic. Using data from a virus discovery project, we validated the risk assessment and ranked the spillover potential of 887 wildlife viruses. We anticipate that SpillOver will be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. This work is a step toward a more comprehensive understanding of the risk of spillover and spread of viruses in the human–animal interface.

Nectar is the reward that most plants offer to pollinators for visitation. The color of nectar is thought to be an important cue for pollinators, but the mechanisms that underlie the production of colored nectar are poorly understood. We show that the red color of the nectar of the blood-red flower Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify a convergent evolution of the red nectar in the hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae. Our findings provide insight into the evolution of a key trait in the plant–pollinator interaction.

The history of Europe is marked by a complex interplay of migration and admixture processes. However, the history of the population of Europe during the period between the migrations of peoples and the arrival of the Romans is largely unknown. Here, we present a genome-wide analysis of a group of women from Bavaria, Germany, who lived mostly between 490 and 550 AD. Our results indicate that the genetic ancestry of these women was heterogeneous and that some of them had a genetic ancestry that is not found in modern Europeans. This suggests that the history of Europe during this period was more complex than previously thought.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) currently spreads in humans and causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how HKU4 and HKU5 transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. First, whereas MERS-CoV prefers human DPP4 over bat DPP4 as its receptor, HKU4 shows the opposite trend. Second, in the absence of exogenous proteases, both MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes mediate pseudovirus entry into bat cells, whereas only MERS-CoV, but not HKU4, mediates pseudovirus entry into human cells. Thus, MERS-CoV, but not HKU4, has adapted to use human cells for efficient human cell

The global spread of infectious diseases is a major public health concern. In resource-scarce settings, such as Cambodia, the detection of emerging pathogens is often hampered by limited laboratory capacity. Here, we demonstrate the feasibility of using a cloud-based metagenomic platform to identify a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens in a periurban hospital in Cambodia. Our findings suggest that the use of mNGS can provide a rapid and cost-effective approach to pathogen surveillance, which can better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens. This can help to better inform public health response and preparedness.

The human genome is replicated in a complex process that involves the replication of the leading strand and the lagging strand. The latter is responsible for replicating the Okazaki fragments, which are the short DNA segments that are synthesized in the 3′ to 5′ direction. The lagging strand replication is a challenging process that requires the replication of the template DNA in the 5′ to 3′ direction, which is the opposite direction of transcription. The replication of the lagging strand is catalyzed by the pol δ, which is a key enzyme in human diseases such as cancer. In this study, we show that the pol δ holoenzyme is not stable and dissociates rapidly from the PCNA sliding clamp.

The origin of life is one of the most important questions in science. In the RNA world hypothesis, the first form of life was RNA-based, but the origin of the genetic code and the evolution of proteins are still poorly understood. In vitro evolution of an RNA polymerase ribozyme has led to a dramatic improvement in its activity and generality. The improved polymerase ribozyme can synthesize a variety of complex structured RNAs, including aptamers, ribozymes, and, in low yield, even tRNA. Furthermore, the polymerase can replicate nucleic acids, amplifying short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of the PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to show that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. We also show that neighborhoods with better initial appearances are more likely to experience larger improvements. Together, these results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which is a monoclonal antibody targeting the IL-6 pathways, can improve the clinical outcome of severe and critical COVID-19 patients immediately. It is an effective treatment to reduce mortality.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but it is also a toxic metal that can cause severe damage to cells. The ability of fungi to sequester copper in the form of xanthocillin-like compounds suggests that these fungi have evolved a mechanism to balance the need for copper with the potential for toxicity. This study demonstrates that the xanthocillin-like compounds are copper-binding molecules and that they have antimicrobial properties. The existence of the xanthocillin-like compound biosynthetic gene cluster in several filamentous fungi suggests that this mechanism of copper homeostasis may be widespread in fungi. This study provides insight into the role of fungal natural products in the regulation of copper homeostasis and the interactions of fungi with other microbes. (Show more)

The formation of tridymite, a low-pressure, high-temperature SiO2 polymorph, in a mudstone at the surface of Mars is a surprising discovery. The tridymitic mudstone has ∼40 wt.% crystalline and ∼60 wt.% X-ray amorphous material and a bulk composition with ∼74 wt.% SiO2. Plagioclase (∼17 wt.% of bulk sample), tridymite (∼14 wt.%), sanidine (∼3 wt.%), cation-deficient magnetite (∼3 wt.%), cristobalite (∼2 wt.%), and anhydrite (∼1 wt.%) are the mudstone crystalline minerals. Amorphous material is silica-rich (∼39 wt.% opal-A and/or high-SiO2 glass and opal-CT), volatile-bearing (16 wt.% mixed cation sulfates, phosphates, and chlorides−perchlorates−chlorates), and has minor TiO2 and Fe2O3T oxides (∼5 wt.%). Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of temperate and boreal forests, but the geographic distribution of frost events and the evolutionary impact of these events on trees are poorly understood. We show that the geographic distribution of frost events is strongly associated with the leaf-out phenology of trees. Areas in which frost events are common, such as eastern North America, harbor tree species with cautious (late-leafing) strategies. Areas in which frost events are rare, such as broad-leaved forests and shrublands in Europe and Asia, instead harbor opportunistic tree species (quickly reacting to warming air temperatures). These strategies are likely to have been selected by the frost events of the past. We estimate that ∼35% of the European and ∼26% of the Asian temperate forest area, but only ∼10% of the North American, will experience increasing late-frost damage in the future. Our findings inform decision-making in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy. (Abridged)

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the developmental origins of Th17 cells are poorly understood. Here, we show that Th17 cells can be divided into two subsets, one of which retains an IL-17A+ phenotype and is required for the development of colitis, whereas the other, which is Stat4+ and T-bet+, is required for the development of Th1 cells. These results suggest that Th17 cells can be divided into two functionally distinct subsets, one of which is required for the development of colitis and the other of which is required for the development of Th1 cells. This dual role of Th17 cells may be important in the pathogenesis of inflammatory bowel disease. (Show more)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by a variety of genetic mutations, but the mechanisms of toxicity are not fully understood. Here, we report a method to rapidly produce induced astrocytes from living ALS patients. These cells can be used to study the disease and to screen for drugs that alleviate toxicity. This will help to identify the mechanisms of toxicity and to develop new therapies.

The gut microbiota of Ixodes scapularis ticks is a complex community of bacteria, fungi, and viruses. We now show that the tick harbors a protein that is able to alter the composition of the gut microbiota, which in turn influences the ability of the tick to transmit human pathogens. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of how a human pathogen exploits an antibacterial protein from an arthropod to alter the gut microbiota and more efficiently colonize the vector. This knowledge will be useful for the development of strategies to control the transmission of vector-borne diseases. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds. The study of the early evolution of the tail is therefore critical for understanding the origin of the modern avian bauplan. Here, we describe a new basal member of the group of birds with a short tail ending in a compound bone (pygostyle), which is a key component of the modern avian tail. The discovery of this new taxon increases our knowledge of the early evolution of the avian tail and the origin of the modern avian bauplan.

The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand the climate system without understanding the role of the water cycle. In this paper, we show that the water cycle is not just a simple feedback, but is itself a climate variable.

The color of animals is an important factor in their survival. In this study, we show that the color of frogs and toads has evolved multiple times, and that the mechanism is the same—the presence of a class of proteins that bind biliverdin. These proteins, hereafter named biliverdin-binding serpins, are most similar to human antitrypsin, but with a remarkable functional diversification. Our results present molecular and functional evidence of recurrent evolution of chlorosis, describe a biliverdin-binding protein in vertebrates, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors.

Hypoxia is a feature of many cancers, and is associated with the maintenance of cancer stem cells, which are responsible for tumor initiation and recurrence. We report that hypoxia induces expression of AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which demethylates N6-methyladenosine (m6A) modifications on mRNA. ALKBH5 expression is dependent on hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF)-1α and HIF-2α, and is required for the maintenance of breast cancer stem cells. Thus, ALKBH5 may be a therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer.

The Bible is one of the most important books in the world. The first pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century, and the source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. Using this method, we analyzed 72 pocket Bibles originating in France, England, and Italy and 293 additional parchment samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for this event is critical to understanding its cause and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics. We present a new age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dating of volcanic ash beds. The age of the extinction is 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. The carbon cycle was highly variable during the extinction, and the recovery was protracted. These results will be critical for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. (Abridged)

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that plays important roles in various biological processes, including circadian rhythm, cancer, and metabolism. Here, we report that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORαΔIEC mice exhibit excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Transcriptome analysis reveals that deletion of RORα leads to up-regulation of NF-κB target genes in IECs. Chromatin immunoprecipitation analysis reveals corecruitment of RORα and histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3) on NF-κB target promoters and subsequent dismissal of CREB binding protein (CBP) and bromodomain-containing protein 4 (BRD4) for transcriptional repression. Together, we demonstrate that RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses, and therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, including inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).
