The spike glycoprotein of the coronavirus that causes COVID-19 has been shown to contain a single amino acid substitution, D614G, that is present in the majority of currently circulating viruses. We have used cryo-electron microscopy to determine the structure of the spike protein in the complex with the receptor-binding domain of the ACE2 receptor. We show that the D614G mutant spike is more open and that this may facilitate binding to the ACE2 receptor. These results suggest that the D614G mutation may have a significant impact on the infectivity of the virus.

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that the pandemic has resulted in a 1.13-y reduction in life expectancy at birth and a 0.87-y reduction at age 65 y, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006.

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry. The chemical hardness and electronegativity of an atom are two of the most important properties of an atom. They are the second- and first-order chemical potentials, respectively. We show that they decrease with pressure, and that they can be used to predict the behavior of the chemical properties of atoms under pressure. We also show that the chemical properties of atoms can be used to predict the behavior of the chemical properties of compounds.

Fire is a key natural process in many ecosystems, but its role in the climate system is uncertain. We show that changes in human demography, rather than climate, are the dominant driver of changes in global fire activity. This has implications for the carbon cycle, as well as for the role of fire in the climate system. Our results suggest that, in some scenarios, fire may be able to mitigate some of the effects of human-caused climate change.

The gut microbiota of animals is a major contributor to host health and fitness. In this study, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, by the host to its symbiotic bacteria is critical for the maintenance of the symbiosis. This glycan is provided only at night, when the host is quiescent, and is catabolized by the symbionts, which in turn modulate the pH of the habitat. This work suggests that the provision of nutrients to the microbiota may be a general mechanism for the maintenance of symbiotic relationships.

Text data are ubiquitous, but it is difficult to identify patterns in them. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data and represent documents as topic sequences. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data.

The Black Death, which occurred in the 14th century, is the most devastating epidemic in human history. It is generally assumed that the bacterium Yersinia pestis was introduced into Europe via the Silk Road system, and that it took over 400 y to establish itself in Europe. However, we show that the introduction of the bacterium into Europe was preceded by climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into the harbors of medieval Europe. Our results suggest that the bacterium was introduced into Europe repeatedly, and that it was not permanently established in Europe until the 16th century. This suggests that the Black Death was not a single introduction, but rather a series of introductions.

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and are important prey for many species of fish, seabirds, and marine mammals. Mass mortality events of these animals are often associated with the presence of a densovirus. Here, we report the discovery of a densovirus in asteroids and provide evidence that it is responsible for a recent mass mortality event.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia and is associated with a poor survival rate. There is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies, ideally targeting AML stem cells that are essential for maintaining the disease. Here, we show that monoclonal antibodies targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. We also show that IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, and we generated an antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. Furthermore, our results provide a proof of principle for the use of antibody-mediated killing of leukemia cells in the treatment of leukemia. This approach may be applicable to other types of cancer. (Show more)

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, which allowed us to reconstruct the history of the Malagasy people. We find that the Malagasy people are a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The settlement history of Madagascar is complex, with a recent arrival of the Malagasy people, but with a sex bias in the colonization of the island. Finally, we find that the genetic diversity of Madagascar is influenced by geography, independent of the settlement history. This study provides a unique view of the history of Madagascar. Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA. Consistent with this observation, we found that cadA and galE are repressed by base pairing with the RNA and base pairing interferes with AzuC translation.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work has the potential to accelerate the development of next-generation antibodies and vaccines against SARS-CoV-2 variants. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Crop experts are the backbone of the US agricultural system, providing information on the status of crops across the country. However, the information they provide is qualitative and subjective, and is not easily amenable to quantitative analysis. We show that this information can be transformed into a continuous probabilistic variable that is better suited to quantitative analysis. We also show that the information provided by the crop experts is not only useful for monitoring crop status, but also for providing earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. Our results show that the crop experts are a valuable resource that can be used to improve the accuracy of agricultural forecasts.

Language is a complex system that involves the ability to store and integrate information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community and the public. However, despite considerable scientific attention in recent decades, the overall response of soil respiration to anticipated climatic warming remains unclear. In this study, we synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The origin of plastids and their subsequent evolution are key questions in the field of evolutionary biology. The study of the molecular evolution of plastid genomes is hindered by the lack of a clear understanding of the functional constraints on their genes. Here, we show that the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. Our findings have implications for the study of the molecular evolution of plastids and their genes, as well as for the study of the origin of plastids.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the impact of climate change on water availability. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. The results also highlight the importance of regional climate models in the assessment of the impact of anthropogenic climate change on regional droughts. View Full-Text

The discovery of quasicrystals in the aftermath of the first nuclear explosion, the Trinity test, has been a source of fascination for the scientific community and the public. The discovery of a new quasicrystal in the red trinitite, the oldest known anthropogenic quasicrystal, provides a unique link between the past and the present.

The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophylls is one of the most productive biological pathways on Earth. The formation of the fifth ring, the isocyclic ring, is the most challenging step in this pathway. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes, one from bacteria and one from plants and cyanobacteria. The former is O2-sensitive, whereas the latter is O2-dependent. Here, we show that the two enzymes are part of a larger family of O2-dependent cyclase enzymes. We also show that the two enzymes have different requirements for additional subunits. These data provide a framework for understanding the evolution of this important reaction. (Show more)

Neuroinflammation is a major feature of many neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis. Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with autoimmune diseases, such as experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE). In this study, we found that ASK1 plays a critical role in the development of EAE. ASK1 deficiency in microglia/macrophages, but not in astrocytes, resulted in a reduction in the early-stage disease, whereas deficiency in astrocytes resulted in a reduction in the later-stage disease. ASK1 signaling in microglia/macrophages was required for the later-stage disease, suggesting a phase-specific role of ASK1 in the development of EAE. Our findings suggest that ASK1 may be a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. (PsycINFO Database Record

The 2012–2014 drought in California was the most extreme in the state’s history. We show that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is largely attributable to anthropogenic warming. Our results suggest that the probability of co-occurring warm and dry conditions will continue to increase in the future.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. Our results show that behavioral inflexibility results from the inability to forget or rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the behavioral phenotypes of autism-risk genes and a potential target for the treatment of autism. It also provides a framework for the identification of the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms. (PsycINFO Database Record

This work is the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date. It also highlights individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. In doing so, it offers a more nuanced understanding of the factors that contribute to the prevalence of negative news content around the world.

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ signaling. Loss-of-function mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensing protein stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) result in severe immune dysfunction and myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and in the pore-forming protein ORAI1, which result in hematological abnormalities and muscle disease, respectively. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated store-operated Ca2+ entry, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. The spread of protein aggregates throughout the brain is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are poorly understood. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease is dependent on the internalization of aggregates, and that this process is dependent on the endocytic machinery. We also show that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide a foundation for understanding the mechanisms of spreading in neurodegenerative diseases and the potential for therapeutic intervention. (Show more)

Bats are increasingly recognized as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are largely unknown. Here, we identified and characterized a protein that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. This protein, named MTX, selectively inhibits the epoxide hydrolase function of leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H) to inhibit LTA4 hydrolysis and the generation of leukotriene B4 (LTB4), a potent lipid chemoattractant for host defense against infection. MTX potently inhibited proinflammatory proteases to induce immune tolerance and maintain high stability. In mouse models, influenza A virus (IAV) H1N1 infection and pathogenicity were exacerbated by MTX but were reversed by interfering with the effects of MTX on LTA4H or exogenous LTB4 administration. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of MTX in the immune system of bats

Cancer is fueled by the metabolism of the cell. In this study, we identify a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells, namely, the deficiency of one-carbon units, which are required for cell growth. We also identify a mechanism of action for a class of small molecules that inhibit the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferse.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation-prone. However, the inclusions that are characteristic of the disease are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these proteins. Rather, the inclusions contain a variety of proteins that are not part of the native interaction partners, and are themselves supersaturated in the cell. We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold atoms. The 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. The device can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The 2D photonic crystal system is a promising platform for the study of many-body physics with cold atoms. The study of Montsechia, a fossil plant from the Cretaceous, has been a challenge for the past 100 y. The plant was first described in 1909 and has been misinterpreted in the past. Now, based upon the study of more than 1,000 specimens, a detailed analysis of Montsechia is presented. The morphology and anatomy of the plant, including aspects of its reproduction, suggest that Montsechia is sister to Ceratophyllum (whenever cladistic analyses are made with or without a backbone). Montsechia was an aquatic angiosperm living and reproducing below the surface of the water, similar to Ceratophyllum. Montsechia is Barremian in age, raising questions about the very early divergence of the Ceratophyllum clade compared with its position as sister to eudicots in many cladistic analyses. Lower Cretaceous aquatic angiosperms, such as Archaefructus and Montsechia, open the possibility that aquatic plants were locally common at a very early stage of angiosperm evolution and that aquatic habitats may have played a major role in the diversification of some early angiosperm lineages. The study of ancient viruses is hampered by the lack of ancient viral sequences. Here we present 10 ancient B19V genomes, which are the oldest viral sequences from humans. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is ∼12.6 kya, and that the rate of evolution of B19V is an order of magnitude lower than previously thought. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. The data presented here will be useful for future studies of ancient viruses. (Show more)

Sea level around the world is rising, and the rate of rise is accelerating. This paper provides a new estimate of the rate of sea level rise over the last 25 y, which is 0.084 ± 0.025 mm/y2. This is the first time that such a precise estimate has been made. The results are consistent with the IPCC 5th Assessment Report (AR5) model projections.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that, for those with less education, each successive birth cohort has a higher prevalence of pain at each age—a result not found for those with a bachelor’s degree. This pattern fits a more general pattern seen in the ongoing erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950. If these patterns continue, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults; importantly, tomorrow’s elderly will be sicker than today’s elderly, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. In this work, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed picture of the fate of the leaving group in a key reaction of tryptophan synthase. This study highlights the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of the active site, including the location of key chemical species, and the role of the cofactor and substrate in the mechanism of the enzyme. This work demonstrates the potential of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into enzyme reactions.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe and often fatal pneumonia caused by the MERS coronavirus (MERS-CoV). There is no specific antiviral treatment for MERS-CoV infection. Here, we show that remdesivir, a nucleotide analog that inhibits the replication of several RNA viruses, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in a nonhuman primate model. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial, and may also be considered for the treatment of other coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This would be of great importance, as there are no antiviral treatments for these viruses either.

The gut microbiota is a critical component of the health of many animals, but the mechanisms by which they interact are poorly understood. Here, we show that the symbiotic relationship between the squid Euprymna scolopes and its bioluminescent symbiont Vibrio fischeri is regulated by the host’s provision of a single glycan. This glycan is catabolized by the symbionts, which in turn is required for the maintenance of the symbiosis. This glycan may be a general cue for the maturation of symbiotic microbiomes, and may be a target for the development of symbiotic therapies.

This study shows that the quality of teacher–student relationships can be improved by teaching teachers to value students’ perspectives and sustain positive relationships while encouraging better behavior. This intervention has the potential to reduce suspensions and improve the quality of life for students and teachers alike.

Alkylated DNA lesions, induced by both exogenous chemical agents and endogenous metabolites, are major contributors to the mutagenesis of the genome. However, the molecular mechanisms of alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that the three regioisomeric EtdT lesions have distinct effects on the fidelity checkpoints of transcription. The transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three EtdT lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The error-free transcriptional lesion bypass route is strongly favored for the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion. In contrast, a dominant error-prone route stemming from GMP misincorporation was observed for the major-groove O4-EtdT lesion. For the N3-EtdT lesion that disrupts base pairing, multiple transcriptional lesion bypass routes were found. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a severe pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease in humans. To better understand the mechanisms of MERS-CoV infection, we engineered MERS viruses with mutations that block the sequential proteolytic events required for virus entry. We found that these mutations affected the ability of MERS-CoV to infect human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into other cell types. These findings suggest that the sequential proteolytic events are important determinants of MERS-CoV virulence.

The food system is responsible for a large proportion of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change. In the UK, the food system is responsible for 22% of greenhouse gas emissions, and this proportion is likely to increase as the population grows and diets change. In this paper, we show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a large-scale catering operation can have a significant impact on meal selection. This is a simple intervention that can be implemented in a range of settings.

The cell surface proteome, the surfaceome, is the interface for engaging the extracellular space in normal and cancer cells. Here we apply quantitative proteomics of N-linked glycoproteins to reveal how a collection of some 700 surface proteins is dramatically remodeled in an isogenic breast epithelial cell line stably expressing any of six of the most prominent proliferative oncogenes, including the receptor tyrosine kinases, EGFR and HER2, and downstream signaling partners such as KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. Addition of a potent MEK inhibitor that blocks MAPK signaling brings each oncogene-induced surfaceome back to a common state reflecting the strong dependence of the oncogene on the MAPK pathway to propagate signaling. In response to the COVID-19 pandemic, many scholars and policy makers are urging the United States to expand voting-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. This paper provides a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effect of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The COVID-19 pandemic has affected the lives of billions of people around the world. The molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the disease is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of the SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 protein. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may be important for immune evasion. This work provides insight into the molecular basis of the unique properties of SARS-CoV-2, which may be targeted for the development of new therapeutics and vaccines. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms underlying this process are not fully understood. Here we show that hypoxia triggers cortical release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), which acts on CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1) to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in cortical astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the pathophysiology of cerebral edema and may lead to the development of new therapies. (Show more)

The world is full of associations. We are interested in the ones that are important, but we don’t want to be misled by spurious ones. This paper describes a way of assessing the strength of associations that is appropriate for the era of big data.

The development of endothelial cells (ECs) is a complex process that requires the coordinated expression of multiple transcription factors. In this study, we identified the transcription factor Ets variant 2 (ETV2) as a direct inducer of EC development. ETV2 is able to induce the expression of multiple key endothelial development factors, including FLI1, ERG, and TAL1, and the expression of endothelial functional molecules, including EGFL7 and von Willebrand factor. Furthermore, ETV2-induced EC development is able to improve blood flow recovery in a hind limb ischemic model. These results indicate that the creation of ETVECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. This study also provides a potential strategy for the generation of ECs for the treatment of vascular disorders. (Show more)

The identification of ALKAL1 and ALKAL2 (also named “augmentor-β” and “augmentor-α” or “FAM150A” and “FAM150B,” respectively) as ligands of anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) has opened a new era in the study of these two orphan RTKs. In this study, we show that these ligands play an important role in zebrafish pigment development. We also demonstrate that the zebrafish genome contains three genes that encode ligands of Alk and Ltk. These ligands are essential for the development of iridophores, a unique type of dermal chromatophore. Our findings establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This study provides a unique model for the study of the function of augmentor ligands and their role in the development of iridophores. This work also provides a foundation for the study of the function of augmentor ligands in other organisms.

Insulin resistance and β-cell dysfunction are two main molecular bases yet to be further elucidated for type 2 diabetes (T2D). Accumulating evidence indicates that stimulator of interferon genes (STING) plays an important role in regulating insulin sensitivity. However, its function in β-cells remains unknown. Herein, using global STING knockout (STING−/−) and β-cell–specific STING knockout (STING-βKO) mouse models, we revealed a distinct role of STING in the regulation of glucose homeostasis through peripheral tissues and β-cells. Specially, although STING−/− beneficially alleviated insulin resistance and glucose intolerance induced by high-fat diet, it surprisingly impaired islet glucose-stimulated insulin secretion (GSIS). Importantly, STING-βKO caused glucose intolerance due to impaired GSIS, indicating that STING is required for normal β-cell function. Islet transcriptome analysis showed that STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, including Glut2, Kcnj11, and Abcc8, contributing to impaired GSIS. Influenza A viruses are responsible for the annual influenza epidemics and occasional severe pandemics. The genome of the influenza A virus is segmented into eight fragments, which complicates the packaging process. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and nonspecifically decreases the amount of viral RNA in the viral particles, resulting in an eightfold increase in empty viral particles. Our experiments indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a complex disease that is characterized by the formation of atherosclerotic lesions in blood vessels. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a multistep process that involves the accumulation of atheroprone phenotypes in the vascular wall. The objective of this study is to investigate the functional role of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) in the flow regulation of atheroprone endothelial phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. Our results demonstrate a critical role of YAP/TAZ in the flow regulation of atheroprone phenotypes and atherogenesis. Therefore, inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. This study may provide a mechanistic understanding of the functional role of YAP/TAZ in the flow regulation of atheroprone phenotypes and atherogenesis and may lead to the development of a novel therapeutic strategy for the treatment of atherosclerosis. Wildfires are a natural part of many ecosystems, but in the United States, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Human-caused wildfires disproportionally occurred where fuel moisture was higher than lightning-started fires, thereby helping expand the geographic and seasonal niche of wildfire. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to show that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. We also show that neighborhoods with better initial appearances are more likely to experience larger improvements. Together, these results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and eco-friendly pest control method. However, the molecular targets of natural repellents in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. The mechanisms of the disease are not fully understood, and the development of effective vaccines and antiviral drugs is a major challenge. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We show that the antiviral treatment favipiravir can reduce the peak viral load and shorten the time to undetectable viral load, whereas treatment given 2 d postinfection is mostly ineffective in accelerating plasma viral load loss. Our results provide a framework for the design of future studies and for the development of effective vaccines and antiviral drugs. (Show more)

Coral bleaching is a natural phenomenon that occurs when corals expel their symbiotic zooxanthellae, the algae that provide corals with nutrients and color. Bleaching is often triggered by environmental stressors, such as warming, but the underlying mechanisms are poorly understood. Here, we show that the breakdown of the coral–zooxanthellae symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may help us to predict the stability of the coral–zooxanthellae symbiosis under future climate change scenarios.

The intestinal epithelium is the main barrier between the host and the external environment. In the presence of tumors, the epithelium becomes leaky, leading to systemic infections and shortened lifespan. Here, we show that the tumor microenvironment triggers a regenerative response in the microbiome, which in turn triggers the tumorigenic process. Our work identifies a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. It also highlights the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our findings have implications for the development of cancer therapies. They also suggest that the microbiome may be a promising target for the treatment of intestinal tumors.

Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but many patients do not respond well to this therapy. In this study, we show that the expression of the orphan receptor ROR1 is up-regulated in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also show that ROR1 promotes the growth of breast cancer cells, and that targeting ROR1 with an antibody may improve the response to chemotherapy in mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may be a promising strategy for improving the response to chemotherapy in patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The start of accelerated Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is often attributed to a sudden poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies and subsequent climate impacts. We show that the start of this event is coincident with the eruption of Mount Takahe, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion. This unique event, with its timing and magnitude, plausibly links the Mount Takahe eruptions to the onset of accelerated Southern Hemisphere deglaciation.

Freshwater fisheries are an important source of food, recreation, and commerce, but are often overlooked. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which we use to assess the role of inland fisheries in food security and biodiversity conservation. We find that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, and that river basins with high biodiversity are also most likely to be heavily fished. Our data can be used to identify areas where inland fisheries are most important for food security and biodiversity conservation. This information can be used to inform the design of policies to protect freshwater ecosystems and the services they provide.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. Due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited. For achieving durable and high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries, the development of negative electrode materials exhibiting a large capacity and low potential without triggering decomposition of water is crucial. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2 delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅

The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the nervous system. In the adult mammalian CNS, however, this ability is lost, and the few remaining neurons that can regenerate are unable to form the complex connections that characterize the mature nervous system. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to be required for regeneration in the adult nervous system. This discovery opens the door to the discovery of additional mechanisms that control the ability of neurons to regenerate.

Recombination is the process by which the genetic material of a cell is exchanged with that of a neighboring cell. It is essential for the maintenance of genetic diversity in populations of cells, and it is also involved in the generation of new traits in the evolution of species. In this paper, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, and we identify some of the mechanisms that may be involved in the generation of new variation.

The brain is organized in networks of functionally related regions. The identification of these networks is a key step in understanding the functional organization of the brain. Here, we show that the metabolic organization of the brain can be used to identify resting state networks. We also show that the metabolic organization of the brain is altered in Parkinson’s disease, and that this alteration can be corrected by dopaminergic therapy.

The 5′ cap structure is a well-known modification of messenger RNA (mRNA) that is essential for efficient translation. In addition to the cap, there are a number of other modifications that have been found on the 5′ end of mRNA. In this study, we describe a 5′ modification of RNA that is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded messenger RNA (mRNA). We show that this modification is produced cotranscriptionally and is essential for efficient translation. This modification may be a new example of a mechanism that regulates the expression of specific subsets of mRNA.

The study of the epigenetic mechanisms that regulate gene expression is of great interest in the field of diabetes. In this work, we show that epigenetic alterations in the DNA methylation of specific loci persist in people with diabetes for several years. This finding supports the existence of epigenetic mechanisms that may explain the metabolic memory phenomenon.

Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of breast cancer tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. This article is protected by copyright. Alcohol dependence is a major public health problem. The present study shows that the gut barrier is altered in a significant number of alcohol-dependent subjects, which may be related to the development of psychological symptoms of the disease. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol-dependent subjects, suggesting that the gut microbiota may be involved in the development of the disease. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The flavor of tomato fruit is largely determined by the volatile chemicals it produces. These chemicals are synthesized from a small set of precursors, and the biosynthetic pathways for many of the compounds are not known. Here, we report the discovery of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. We also show that this gene is required for the production of a large number of other compounds in N. benthamiana, providing a proof of principle for the use of this gene in the production of a range of chemicals. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato flavor. (Show more)

The loss of biodiversity and the warming of the planet are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of the Earth’s ecosystems. Here we show that the impacts of these two threats are not independent of each other. We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning changes as the planet warms, and that this change is driven by changes in the thermal tolerance of species. Our results highlight the importance of considering the impacts of climate change on biodiversity in the context of the functioning of ecosystems.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key hub of the hippocampal circuit. It is thought to create a map of local space, based on the activity of grid, head-direction (HD), border, and object-vector (OV) cells. How these cell types are organized anatomically is debated. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to examine the topographic arrangement of spatially modulated neurons in the superficial layers of MEC and adjacent parasubiculum during unrestrained behavior. Our data suggest that grid cell networks might be largely distinct from those of border, HD, and OV cells. These findings have implications for understanding the organization of the MEC and its role in spatial navigation.

Flowering is a complex process, which is controlled by a large number of genes. In this study, we show that flowering can be controlled by a signal, which is produced in one plant and is able to induce flowering in another plant. This study demonstrates that flowering is a signal-based process, which is controlled by a large number of signals, which are able to travel between plants.

The dopamine systems of the brain powerfully influence movement and motivation. Here, we describe a previously unrecognized system of specialized clusters of dopamine-containing neurons that are densely arborized within the striosome and that project to the striatum and back to the striosome. This system, which we term the “striosome–dendron bouquet,” likely represents subsystems with the nigro–striato–nigral loop that are affected in human disorders including Parkinson’s disease. The striosome–dendron bouquets are likely critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease.

We all have a sense of when we feel connected to others. But how do we know when two people are connected? We show that the speed with which people respond to each other is a robust predictor of how connected they feel. This signal is used by others to assess the quality of the connection between two people. Our findings suggest that the speed with which we respond to others is a fundamental signal of connection.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the pacemaker of the heart. SAN cells are responsible for setting the heart rate, and their function is critical for maintaining a normal heart rate. In this study, we found that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is expressed in the specialized cardiomyocytes of the SAN and plays a critical role in the regulation of SAN function. Our findings provide insights into the mechanisms that regulate SAN function and may lead to the development of new therapies for heart failure. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, its function in plant defense against insect herbivores has been controversial. In this study, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA may interact to promote plant defense against insect herbivores. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the beneficial effects of Si on plant resistance against insect herbivores and may lead to the development of Si-based pest management strategies. The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is still poorly understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is important for the function of macrophages.

Language is a complex system that involves the ability to store and integrate information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a challenge due to the presence of the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells. Here, we show that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver biomolecules across the cell wall. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructures are important design parameters for the internalization and gene silencing efficiencies. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is a step toward the development of DNA nanostructures as a tool for plant biotechnology. (Show more)

Eutrophication is a major threat to the health of lakes and coastal ecosystems worldwide. In the United States, the majority of nutrient pollution comes from small tributaries that drain surrounding watersheds. However, decades of monitoring and regulatory efforts have focused on large water bodies, leaving small tributaries largely unaddressed. We show that small tributaries can be a significant source of nutrients to coastal areas, and that their nutrient loads are often high for their size. Our findings suggest that nutrient management efforts should be expanded to small tributaries to reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of the environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “fine-tuning problem” in cosmology, where the rare combinations of initial conditions that led to the observed universe are biased toward states that are far from equilibrium.

This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the mechanisms underlying the effects of NMDA-receptor antibodies on the brain. It also provides a framework for understanding the effects of other neuropsychiatric drugs on the brain.

The history of abrupt climate change is a key area of research in Earth system science. Here, we present a study of an abrupt climate change event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the event was linked to a large injection of organic matter into the ocean, which led to an increase in atmospheric CO2 and a biodiversity nadir. We also show that the event was linked to an increase in nutrient fluxes and thermocline stratification, which may have been driven by the release of stored heat in the deep ocean. This work provides insights into the mechanisms that led to the event and the potential impacts of such events on the Earth system.

The palm oil industry is the largest consumer of deforestation-prone tropical peatlands in the world. In response, many major corporations and countries have made commitments to purchase only “sustainable” palm oil. Certification is the tool most used to fulfill these procurement policies, and around 20% of global palm oil production was certified by the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) in 2017. However, the effect of certification on deforestation in oil palm plantations remains unclear. Here, we show that certification is associated with reduced deforestation in Indonesia, the leading producer of palm oil. Nevertheless, most plantations contained little residual forest when they received certification. As a result, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. The exocyst complex is a key regulator of the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. In this study, we discovered a small molecule that binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental feature of animal biology, and the sex of an individual is often a defining characteristic of its phenotype. In vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus, resulting in two sexes, or by multiple loci, resulting in more than two sexes. In this study, we show that the multiple alleles of a single locus can result in a modular system of sex determination, where the sex of an individual is determined by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. This modular system of sex determination provides a context for understanding the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations.

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by two distinct classes of reactive oxygen species (ROS) that are generated by the metabolism of vitamin A. One class of ROS is generated by the oxidation of the lipofuscin pigments that accumulate in the retina. The other class of ROS is generated by the photodegradation of the lipofuscin pigments. We show that the accumulation of iron in the retina promotes the photodegradation of the lipofuscin pigments. This work has implications for the understanding of the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the elderly. It also has implications for the development of strategies to prevent or treat age-related macular degeneration. (Read more)

Predators are the main drivers of biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. However, the evolution of their feeding strategies is poorly understood. Here we show that the evolution of the feeding strategy of a group of predators, siphonophores, has been shaped by the evolution of their feeding structures. Our results show that the evolution of siphonophore feeding structures has been shaped by the evolution of their prey. This study contributes to understanding the evolution of the feeding strategies of predators, and the role of morphological evolution in the diversification of food webs.

The human hand is a complex and highly specialized structure. The evolution of the human hand has been linked to the evolution of modern human behavior, and the fossil record of the hominin hand has been a key to understanding the origins of modern human behavior. However, the fossil record of the hominin hand is sparse between 800,000 and 1.8 My old, a time interval well documented for the emergence and subsequent proliferation of Acheulian technology. Here we show that the third metacarpal styloid was present in a 1.42-Myr-old fossil from Kenya, suggesting that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato.

Cancer is fueled by the metabolism of the cell. One-carbon units are required for the synthesis of nucleotides, which are the building blocks of the cell. In this study, we identify a metabolic target of cancer, serine hydroxymethyltransferase, and develop a small-molecule inhibitor that blocks the enzyme in cancer cells. We also identify a metabolic vulnerability of cancer, the inability to import glycine, and develop a strategy to exploit this vulnerability. These studies provide a foundation for the development of a new class of cancer therapeutics.

The world is facing a triple crisis of food, nutrition, and environmental security. In this study, we show that deforestation is having a negative impact on people’s diets in rural Tanzania. This study has important implications for policy makers, who need to consider the role of natural landscapes in meeting nutrition goals, particularly in low- and middle-income countries.

Mechanization has been a key driver of the Green Revolution, allowing for the expansion of food production. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
